instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulsing.
threads.message:
Have this board that wasn't powered up and had corrosion. Cleaned up the corrosion and replaced damaged <RESISTOR>R8156</RESISTOR>. 
<SIGNAL>PP5V_SR4RS3</SIGNAL> pulses, so does <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and all the big coils. 
SPI Bus Termination resistors good
I removed J6100 and also flashed know good BIOS with same result.

Any suggestions.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulsing.
threads.message: Does it stay on in SMC bypass mode?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulsing.
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulsing.
threads.message:
Remove <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and test the board again.
Also test removing <CHIP>U8130</CHIP>.
Be sure no corrosion at <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> and surrounding resistors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulsing.
threads.message: Pulsing still present with <TRANSISTOR>Q8150</TRANSISTOR> and <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> removed. Also confirmed no corrosion under <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> pulsing.
threads.message:
Heat CPU with good flux.
May be just a problem caused by accumulated crap between its balls.
You should also reball SMC...
